awd_titl_txt: Risk effects in large carnivore-ungulate interactions: relationships between direct predation rates, antipredator responses and the costs of response.
awd_abstract_narration: Predation is one of the most important factors affecting the size of wildlife populations.  To manage and conserve wildlife populations, we must understand how predation limits prey numbers  For many decades,  research on predation has focused solely on the effect of direct killing, but recent studies show that the costs of avoiding predation (or 'risk effects') can also have strong effects.  In particular, antipredator behavior can lead to changes in nutrition that reduce reproduction, and it is easy to mistakenly attribute such responses to factors other than predation (for example, limitation by the availability of food).  This study will (1) measure a broad set of antipredator responses to variation in the risk of predation for a broad set of species, (2) measure the nutritional costs of these responses, and (3) test for effects on reproduction.  By examining the responses of several prey species under varying environmental conditions, the study will identify factors that control the magnitude of predation risk effects. Overall, this study will advance our understanding of the ways that large carnivores affect populations of ungulates.  Because large-carnivore ungulate systems are in decline worldwide, the results will be of immediate value for conservation and management. This project will also train undergraduate and graduate students in animal behavior and conservation research and provide international experience for those students who will be working at the research area in Zambia.  Due to the international component the project is jointly supported by the Behavioral Systems Cluster and the Office for International Science and Engineering Global Venture Fund.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Most species alter their behavior in response to predation risk, and considerable evidence shows that these responses often carry costs (for example, prey are often less effective at obtaining food when they must also avoid predators).  Although the existence of such costs is well established, very little is known about their magnitude under natural conditions, and this must be known to properly understand how predators limit prey populations.  Here for the first time we examined the responses of complete herbivore prey communities to all of the the large carnivores that prey on them, in three Zambian ecosystems. 

We  tested the relationship between direct predation and the strength of antipredator responses  using data from Liuwa Plain National Park, South Luangwa National Park and Kafue National Park to: (1) quantify the vigilance of each ungulate species with each predator species within 450 m (reactive vigilance) and farther than 450 m (proactive vigilance),  (2) quantify how vigilance of each prey species was affected by te longterm use of their location by each predator, (3) test for trade-offs between vigilance and foraging within each prey species, (4) quantify patterns of predation on each species in the ungulate guild by each species in the predator guild, (4) quantify the abundance of each prey species so that patterns of predation could be converted to individual risk, and (5) test the relationship across predator-prey pairs between direct predation and antipredator behavior.

We found strong repsonses of prey to the risk of predation, as shown byb increased vigilance, decreased movement and decreased foraging.  Responses to both short term and long term varation in riks were strong, and these responses affected one another.  While there was considerable variation in the strength of behavioral responses by each prey species to each predator, the strength of these responses was not correlated to rates of direct predation on each prey species by each predator.  Both of these results are new, and they present serious complication for the design of field studies to measure the total lmiting effect that predators have on their prey, because most studies of the costs of avoiding predation do not examine both long term and short term variation in risk, and most studies assume that the strength of antipredator responses will be correlated with direct predation.

The large carnivore species that we studied (Afrrican wild dogs, cheetahs, leopards, lions and spotted hyenas) are threatened or endangered, and this study provided extentive data on their numbers, distibution and trends (together with data on the prey populations that support them) that is of immediate and direct value for management and conservation,

 

FInally, the project provided graduate training to five students who benefited tfrom international collaboration.  Three of these students were Zambians who received graduate eduction in the US and have returned to work in ecology and wildlife conservation in Africa.  Dozens of US undergraduate students participated in the project as assisitants to these graduate students, receiving valuable STEM research experience.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2017
Modified by: Scott R Creel
